captions.text:
So the PS5 is going to be a souped up PS4
that looks like someone sat on a giant licorice

allsort and the Xbox is just gonna keep adding
Exes to its name like a serial divorcee, but

who fucking cares? Why are we still tethering
huge plastic bricks to televisions like millstones

around the neck of the future? It&#39;s 2020 for
fuck&#39;s sake. We should be downloading multicolour

techdreams from cyberspace to our holographic
skateboards. That&#39;s why, now we&#39;re between

big release periods, I felt it was time to
give Google Stadia a go. A console without

a console where all you need is a net connection
and a login and games are streamed to you

with no installation required. Which you&#39;d
think people would be more excited about.

Having to own a console is kind of a pain
in the arse when they&#39;re expensive and ugly

and you could be using the shelf space for
your child&#39;s yearbook or a charcuterie board.

And as for high end gaming PCs, it&#39;s like
they took the Monolith from 2001 and decorated

it for Christmas and now I have to figure
out how to arrange my office around it. But

then again, it&#39;s not like there&#39;s no console
at all, you&#39;re just not allowed to touch it.

It&#39;s in a basement at Google somewhere and
they use the heat coming off it to dry their socks.

So maybe Stadia isn&#39;t catching on so well
because people find it hard to get invested

without being able to choose their console&#39;s
colour or cover it in unicorn stickers. At

any rate, I signed up for the Stadia Pro first
month free trial, for what is modern life

if not one first month free trial after another,
remembering to put a reminder on my calendar

because 90% of the income these subscription
services generate comes from people forgetting

to unsubscribe before the month is up, in
Stadia&#39;s case it certainly can&#39;t come from

selling games, &#39;cos there&#39;s only, like, nine
on there. Incidentally, having to pay sixty

bucks on top of the subscription to play Doom
Eternal does feel like a taking of the piss,

jaded consumer drone though I am. Not sure
why. Maybe it&#39;s &#39;cos we never get to be so

much as in the same postcode as the data and
if our internet goes down we essentially paid

sixty bucks to sit imagining how much fun
it would be to play Doom Eternal. Fuck, don&#39;t

give them ideas. You ever take a look around
and think about what your entertainment options

would be reduced to if your internet was down
and your hard drives were wiped? I&#39;d just

have to watch my Columbo box set over and
over again. Or read a book. Like a fucking caveman.

Whatever, there&#39;s still a bunch of free games
thrown in with the pro subscription, so I

tried some of those and hey, no installation,
straight into the game, it&#39;s like a corporation

didn&#39;t lie to me for once. No significant
controller delay that I noticed. I tried it

on my main PC with a cable connection and
on my laptop with Wifi, and while the latter

was very choppy at times I was still pretty
jazzed to be playing Serious Sam on my laptop

without it melting straight through my legs.
There was a fair bit of artefacting, almost

as if all we&#39;re essentially doing is streaming
web video, so this won&#39;t be your system of

choice if you&#39;re the kind of person who won&#39;t
give a game the time of day if it can&#39;t manage

120FPS and more pixels than there are atoms
in the universe, but for everyone else, the

games are playable at least. You might be
at a disadvantage if you&#39;re playing PUBG and

are trying to keep track of a distant sniper
through a haze of image compression, but for

the most part, even if you get knocked down
to 320p you can still have some fun as long

as you can tell which blob is you and which
blob is everything other than you.

So while the general quality could be a problem,
I fear the main one, my little velvet fucksocks,

is games. I know, it&#39;s such a bore, isn&#39;t
it, having to sucker people into a subscription

service AND provide them content. It&#39;s like,
running a dairy farm would be so much easier

if you didn&#39;t have to keep feeding the cows
and making sure they don&#39;t die and shit. Right

now there&#39;s just a limited selection of triple-A
titles that everyone stopped talking about

around the same time they stopped talking
about Russia annexing the Ukraine, and as

for the all-important exclusives, there&#39;s
little more than what meagre scraping of indie

titles could be snuck out of the Epic Store&#39;s
shopping basket. Gylt is about the only one

worth dwelling on, it&#39;s a stealth horror adventure
where you&#39;re a little girl in a red coat - in

the world of arty indie games, a character
wearing a red or hooded coat goes right next

to the free space on the bingo card because
ooh red riding hood lost in the scary woods

I got your clever allusion Mr. Writer let&#39;s
rub our massive brains together in mutual

recognition - who goes looking for their missing
cousin who was being bullied and ends up in

a dark spooky version of their high school
full of monsters unsubtly themed around bullying

and it&#39;ll probably turn out that the bullies
was you the whole time.

Hardly a spoiler, the game&#39;s named Gylt for
fuck&#39;s sake, not Gynerally Feeling Prytty

Okay About Thyngs. So in brief it&#39;s Silent
Hill 2 meets the Magic School Bus. It&#39;s certainly

got the Silent Hill level structure - you
explore a cluster of rooms looking for the

bird statue or tin of baked beans that opens
the very obtusely locked door that prevents

you from moving to the next cluster of rooms.
Also, monsters. But the game&#39;s major flaw

is that it&#39;s just way too easy and therefore
not scary. Hide from the monster, it&#39;ll kill

yer. Oh shit! Wait, here&#39;s a flashlight, it
kills the monster if you aim it at their weak

spot. Well I guess that&#39;s still pretty skillful.
Is it? Sorry, here&#39;s an instant kill stealth

attack as well. No, I wasn&#39;t criticizing,
I meant - AND here&#39;s an instant stun attack.

And a freeze attack. Oh god there aren&#39;t enough
chest high walls around, are there, here&#39;s

ten billion more. Jesus, I know this has a
kiddie vibe but for most of the time I was

using health items for idle mid afternoon
snacking I had so fucking many. So, not much

else to say about Gylt, it&#39;s hardly a hot
app. I do wonder why the main character was

looking for a younger cousin when it could
easily have been a younger sister.

That makes me think the story writer was working
through some unresolved issues they had with

their own cousin growing up, but didn&#39;t want
to air the dirty laundry in too public a forum,

and so signed up to be a Google Stadia exclusive,
thus ensuring it would never be heard from

again. The only other exclusive worth mentioning
is Crayta, a game creation tool kinda like

Dreams, but if you thought Dreams&#39; problem
was that there was just a little bit too much

incentive to do unpaid work to prop up someone
else&#39;s IP on a delivery system you have no

stake in that might not exist in two years,
then here&#39;s all that with less features. Crayta&#39;s

fundamental issue is that you cannot possibly
expect amateur developers to care when Google

themselves do not. And that&#39;s the impression
that fully surrounds Stadia like family pets

around a wobbly dining table - Google could
put up more games and advertise more and post

more updates when how they&#39;re gonna make it
less choppy, but they don&#39;t seem to care,

presumably because they&#39;re Google and don&#39;t
have to. If this were Nintendo the senior

staff would be lucky to have any fingers left
to hack off in shame but Google? They probably

made their losses back in the time it takes
to search for &quot;Larry Page burnt in effigy&quot;.
